Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Surface Immobilized Growth Factors for Low Cost Serum-Free Cell Culture
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will create a microcarrier with immobilized growth factors for adherent cultured cells. This advancement in cell culture biomaterials promises to remove the variability associated with growth factors in liquid media while increasing cell culture workflow efficiency. The project is to identify an efficient reaction mechanism for coupling protein, including animal serum and purified fibroblast growth factor (FGF), to the surface of a previously developed magnetic alginate microcarrier. The resulting product is anticipated to have significant benefits over traditional flask culture methods and will provide enabling technology to next generation drug discovery and therapeutics as primary and stem cells become the cell types of choice.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is the use of immobilized growth factors to advance the basic understanding of cell-substrate interactions. Currently, the major cost for culturing primary and stem cells is the cell growth media, which contains costly purified growth factors. Reducing the amount of growth factors necessary for culture will directly reduce the cost per cell. Furthermore, this product will prove valuable for therapeutic applications including cell-based therapies in which cGMP growth factors would be especially costly. Finally, a growth factor-conjugated microsphere will be a useful basic research platform for understanding the role of "immobilized" growth factors in vivo, which is important for creating bio-scaffolds and regenerative implants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Cell culture is a method of expanding various animal tissues for biomedical research and drug discovery. The cells generated with this method are used for a wide range of applications including drug toxicity testing, biomedical device development and therapeutic protein production. Maintaining cells in culture requires supplementing the liquid growth medium with growth factor proteins. These growth factors stimulate the cells to multiply and promote cell behaviors similar those found in the body. Growth factors however are costly and a limiting factor in cell-based research. Our SBIR Phase I: “Surface Immobilized Growth Factors for Low Cost Serum-Free Cell Culture” evaluated the feasibility of a new method for cell culture.

 

Global Cell Solutions’ proposed method binds the growth factor to the surface on which the cells expand. Traditionally growth factors float in the liquid medium but evidence suggested immobilized growth factors could elicit the same growth response at a lower concentration. Our results indicate that a surface immobilized growth factor, epidermal growth factor, can stimulate far greater cellular expansion compared to epidermal growth factor floating in the growth medium. This suggests a new technology for cell culture based on Global Cell Solutions GEM™ product line can lower the cost and complexity of current cell culture methods. 

 

Two cell culture applications in which the proposed technology would have substantial impact include primary cell culture and biopharmaceutical production. Primary cells are produced from donated tissue and provide an experimental model more like the human body than current cell models. Unfortunately primary cells typically require costly growth factor mixtures to stay alive and expand. The proposed technology would lower the cost of primary cell culture by lowering the amount of growth factor required thereby increasing the adoption and application of primary cells. Biopharmaceutical production is a process that uses cell culture to produce an engineered protein for human therapy. Common examples include insulin and human growth hormone. Manufacturers of biopharmaceuticals are faced with the challenge of separating the desired product from the contaminating proteins in solution. An immobilized growth factor would simplify the purification process and conceivably the entire production process beginning with growth media formulation. In both examples the proposed Global Cell Solutions’ technology is simplifying culture and decreasing the use of a costly limiting resource in cell culture.
